A/N: Who’s in love with baby Jungkook and Jimin already?  Me is!  I am.  Whatever.  

The italics in this story are past conversations or thoughts.

Warnings: Some bad words (bad Yoo-yoo!)

WC: 3,593

Masterlist

1. Fun-er-ule

2. It’s Where It Goes

           It’s funny how easily people underestimate kids, especially when it comes to their memory.  Yoongi was sure the boys would forget that afternoon, would ask the next day where their dad was, would forget why they were staying at his and not grandma’s now, would not remember the last time they had spent the night at his apartment.

           Yoongi is wrong about a lot of things.

           He made them carry things purely out of necessity, knowing full well they were tiny children who shouldn’t be burdened with such things, especially up a flight of stairs, but Yoongi wasn’t about to make twenty trips when they had two hands and were capable of walking.  They went slowly, sure, but they both had a look of determination on their faces as they trudged up ahead of him.  Yoongi wasn’t foolish or mean enough to have them walk behind him; if they started to fall, he’d drop whatever he was holding to make sure to catch them.  He assumed Jungkook would poop out first purely due to his age, but he dumped his load and stood waiting for Yoongi to go out again while Jimin started to look around the apartment, trying to find his place.

           “Stay here, okay, Jimin?  Jungkook and I will be right back.”  The boy waved a hand at them, so Yoongi took Jungkook’s and headed back downstairs, risking a smile at how excited the boy seemed to be simply going up and down a flight of stairs.  Kids love work until they realize it’s work, Yoongi figured.  They hadn’t quite brought everything from his brother’s. For one, it wouldn’t all fit. Yoongi’s place was barely a loft, and his nephews were spoiled.  Getting them to pare down their toys would be difficult, but if they can go a week without asking for a certain toy, he’ll know they must not have valued it very much. Jungkook had his bunny, and Jimin had his blanket, and maybe Yoongi can maintain his sanity if can stay content with those.

           He and Jungkook couldn’t have been gone more than five minutes unloading the car he had borrowed from his parents, so for Jimin to have made such a fantastic mess in such a short period of time was purely unbelievable.  He had thrown their clothes everywhere, for one thing, and he was trying to pull Yoongi’s mattress off of its low frame.  A pot in the windowsill had somehow fallen off, the dirt spilled over the floor like an overturned paint can, the succulent in no hurry to go anywhere as long as no one stepped on it.

           “Jimin,” Yoongi said, surprised at how calm he sounded despite how upset he felt.

           “Not right, not right,” Jimin muttered, tugging fruitlessly on the mattress.

           “What are you doing?” Yoongi tried again, putting the bags down he was carrying and sharing a confused look with Jungkook.

           “Not right, it’s not right,” Jimin said again.  Sighing, Yoongi patted Jungkook’s head and went over to Jimin, stepping over the piles of clothes and toys already taking up his floor.

           “What’s not right?”

           “This goes there,” Jimin said, pointing to the bed and then toward the wall with the TV.

           “Why does it go there?” Yoongi asked seriously.  

           “It’s where it goes,” Jimin said, as if that helped prove his point.  Yoongi sat on the floor and leaned against the mattress, thereby making it even more impossible for Jimin to move it.  The boy huffed and stomped his foot.  “Yoo-yoo!”

           “Jimin.  This is my bed, and it stays here.”

           “No, it was there!  It was there,” Jimin said, pointing again.

           “It was there, like, last year,” Yoongi said slowly, furrowing his brow. Having found his rabbit, Jungkook came over and pulled on the mattress once, too, before shrugging and giving up.

           “Heavy.”

           “It is,” Yoongi nodded, trying not to smile the boy started to climb on top of it. He gave him a boost up by pushing on his bottom, watching as Jungkook half-stood, half rested on his knees to look out the window.  “Jimin, my bed used to be over there.  Do you remember the last time you spent the night?”  Jimin nodded as he rushed to the other side of the small room.  It was lined with shelves, book shelves, a TV stand, and cabinets and nooks filled with supplies.  His dresser and desk stood against the opposite wall while his mattress was under the wall with the window by the door to the patio because, believe it or not, it was the spot that actually got the least amount of sun.

           “We made a fort!” Jimin recalled, waving his hands over his head.  “And the ceiling was so high.”

           “This high!” Jungkook explained, waving his hands over his head, too. Yoongi was pretty positive the younger boy didn’t remember this at all, and he doubted Jimin really did, either. Still, the boy seemed adamant.  

           “I remember,” Yoongi said, not choosing to remind the pair how much of a mess they had gotten into and how he had taken them back to his brother with a footnote that read something along the lines of: Never again, hyung.

           He had gotten the boys changed and laid them down after getting wet from the pond at the funeral home, only waking them up when his mom had told him if he let them sleep for too long they wouldn’t sleep that night.  Plus, it had been dinner time.  Disturbing them had been almost as hard as trying to explain that their dad was dead to them.  To disrupt their nap would be to disrupt their peace, and they were going to need all of the time they could get in blissful ignorance before being rudely awakened to the fact that their new home was a tiny apartment owned and occupied by the uncle.  But he had shaken them lightly on the mats, unable to hide a smile at how they smacked their lips and wrung their hands and blinked their sleepy eyes up at him.  The promise of food had been an effective lure, during which they had proceeded to get dirty again, plus moving boxes and bags had gotten them sweaty, and Yoongi looked around the room and sighed, unsure if cleaning or taking a bath first was the right thing to do.  He had no idea how any of this was going to work. He could already foresee his electric bill tripling, his water bill doubling, and his time to work dwindling. His brother had left him money, but all the money in the world couldn’t buy time, and certainly couldn’t buy what his sons would actually need.

           “Jimin, Jungkook,” Yoongi said, leaning his head back on the couch and unbuttoning his shirt.  “We need to talk about a few rules, okay?  Can you both come sit here and listen?”  Jungkook wiggled backwards off the bed, his little legs dangling over the side until Yoongi reached up to help him, and Jimin finally sighed exaggeratedly and sat down on his knees again, his hands pressed against his thighs as he waited.  “First, you need to clean up the mess you made.  I’m going to show you where to put your clothes and where to put your toys, okay?” Two bobbing heads.  “Then we’re going to take a bath, no discussion. Then we’re going to go to sleep.”

           “But we need a bed to sleep,” Jimin pointed out.

           “You’ll have to sleep with me tonight, okay?”  The idea seemed more than okay to the boys who both nodded enthusiastically.  Yoongi had no idea where he would put another bed, much less two, even if they were child-sized, in his apartment, but he could come up with a solution later.  

“And I mean it.  Sleep.  Okay,” Yoongi said, peeling off his shirt and pointing to the two bottom shelves by the TV. “See those red and blue bins? That’s where your toys need to go. Your shoes need to go by the door.” The instructions seemed clear enough, but the boys simply sat there, their eyes wide and mouths in little “o” shapes.  “What?” Yoongi frowned before the two boys were clamoring toward him.

           “Yoo-yoo, what’s this?”

           “Flower,” Jungkook said, poking Yoongi’s forearm hard enough that he flinched a little.

           “You’ve seen my tattoos before.”

           “Not this one,” Jimin said, patting the one on his ribcage carefully.

           “Oh, I guess that’s true,” Yoongi said, looking down at the boy.  He could distinctly remember a time his brother forced him to go to the beach.  Jungkook had been just a baby, then, and Jimin was probably too young to remember it. Yoongi hated the water, and he hated being shirtless, but he knows he was that day.  It may be hard to remember what the water and the sun felt like, but the stares were impossible to forget.  His heart leapt and fell over, but Yoongi wasn’t going to cry.  “How about this?”  He cleared his throat.  “Once you pick up your toys, we can take a bath, and I’ll show you all of them.”

           “More tat’oos?” Jungkook whispered, and Yoongi held back a snort, nodding and patting his head.  “Let’s go, Jimin, glean, glean.”  Yoongi shouldn’t have been so surprised when Jungkook took the blue bin and Jimin took the red bin.  He hadn’t even told them to separate their toys, but they were smarter than he gave them credit for.  Perhaps smarter than anyone had given them credit for, even their dad.  

           Shaking his head, Yoongi sat up and started to pick up the clothes Jimin had thrown around, gathering them all in a pile he placed by his dresser.  He had already tried to make as much room as possible, stuffing his small closet as full as possible with his own clothes to make space in the drawers.  Kids’ clothes were also tiny, thankfully, so it looked like everything they had brought so far would fit in the bottom drawer.

           “Yoo-yoo,” Jimin said, wiggling against Yoongi’s back.  Jungkook stood by his shoulder, still holding his bunny, the boy’s eyes already getting droopy again.  “We done!”

           “Oh?” Yoongi said, turning around to see his floor clean again.  A few bags still sat by the door, but most of them held food leftover from the wake.  “Good job, you two.”  Jimin beamed, and Jungkook smiled slightly, hugging his bunny closer to his chest. “We need to clean up the plant and those bags now.”

           “But you said bath!”

           “And tat’oos,” Jungkook whispered.

           “Well, I forgot about the plant and the food.  We have to put the food up so we can eat tomorrow.  And if don’t pick up the plant, it will die.  Do you want it to die?”  It was the wrong question.  The wrong word.  Yoongi knew immediately and somehow managed to keep his curse in his own head.

           “Don’t wanna die,” Jungkook mumbled.  Jimin looked like he was about to melt or explode right there.

           “You’re not going to.  The plant will be fine,” Yoongi said, scurrying across the floor to pick it up to show them. “Look, it’s fine.  Jimin, can you—do you see that cup by the sink?  No, you can’t reach that.  Here, hold this,” he said, holding out the plant still in a little bed of dirt to the boy.  Jimin held out both of his hands carefully and took the plant as if it was a precious relic.  Brushing his hands on his already dirty pants, Yoongi patted him on the head and stepped into the kitchen to grab a glass.  “Okay, you can put it in here.”  Jimin did, transferring the plant to the cup carefully as Jungkook looked on.  “Good job.  Now, this needs to go back in the windowsill.  Think you can do that?”

           “I can do it,” Jimin nodded seriously, taking the cup and walking slowly toward the bed.  Yoongi watched as he tried to decide what to do as he bent down to pick up the biggest pieces of the broken pot.

           “Maybe Jungkook can hold it while you climb up, then he can pass it to you?” Yoongi suggested, and Jungkook hurried to help.  The plan seemed to work, and Yoongi swept up the rest of the dirt and sharp bits quickly, thankful the boys seemed patient for the time being. They stayed quiet while he put the food away, too, and at one point when he turned away from the fridge Jungkook was behind him, handing him another container. “Thank you,” he said, meaning every word.  By the time he was done, Jimin was lying on his side on the mattress, his eyes open but blinking rapidly.  “Uh uh,” Yoongi said, “bath first.”  He expected more pouting and whining, as kids who were tired usually got that way, but the pair seemed to grow quieter.  They stood against the wall while he stopped up the tub and began to fill it, dipping his fingers under the faucet a few times to check the temperature.  

           “Can you undress yourselves?” Yoongi said after pouring some bubble bath in the water, which, yes he had lying around.  Jimin nodded and began working on his shirt and pants while Jungkook simply held his bunny and stood watching Yoongi.  “Jungkook?”

           “He needs help ‘cause he’s a baby,” Jimin explained.

           “’m not,” Jungkook muttered, but Yoongi squatted down next to him anyway, holding out his hand.

           “Bunny can’t get wet, so let me put him on the counter.  Then you can take your shirt off.”  The look Jungkook gave Yoongi almost made him laugh it was so absurd. Eventually, with Jimin naked and bouncing on his toes beside him, Jungkook handed his bunny over, watching carefully as Yoongi put it on the counter and then raised his eyebrows. “Shirt.”  Yoongi and his mom had helped them get out of their suits earlier, but he had a t-shirt and pants with elastic on them now, so he just needed to pull and tug, and they would come off.  Still, Jungkook reached for the hem and started to pull it off, but the second it went over his head he started to thrash around.   “Hey,” Yoongi said, tugging the shirt off immediately, “there you go.”  Jungkook’s eyes were wide, and he tried to reach for his bunny, but Yoongi grabbed his hands and squeezed them gently.  

           “Hey, bath first.  You’re okay. Pants now, alright?”  Shaking his head, Jungkook stamped his foot.

           “Yoo-yoo, can I get in?” Jimin said, growing impatient.  Yoongi nodded, watching him climb over the edge as he took off Jungkook’s pants.  The little boy went a little limp against him as he did all of the work, taking off his pull-up, too.  Realizing the boy must be on his last leg, Yoongi took pity on him, picking him up and placing in the bath next to Jimin.

           “Where are your toys?” Jimin said once his brother was beside him.

           “I don’t have any toys,” Yoongi said, unzipping his slacks and slipping them off.  He was reminded why he hated them as soon as they pooled at his ankles.  Legs didn’t technically need to breathe, and neither did his waist, but they suddenly felt like they could again.  “Bath time is for getting clean, not playing.”

           “Boring,” Jimin pouted, smacking the water and sending a spray of water in Jungkook’s face.  The boy whined and rubbed at his eyes.

           “Bath time is for getting clean,” Yoongi repeated, “not making a mess.”

           “Boring,” Jimin said again, but before he could slap the water again Yoongi took off his boxers and tried to slip into the bath next to them.  “Ah, Yoo-yoo!” the boy practically screamed, pointing as his uncle.  Jungkook followed his finger, and his pout disappeared as his eyes got a little wide.

           “Your pee-pee is big,” Jungkook said, sounding wowed.

           “My—” Yoongi looked down and blinked before rolling his eyes.  He picked Jungkook up a little to make room for himself before sitting down, being careful not to let the water slosh up and over the sides.  “Don’t call it that.”

           “But it’s so big.  Why’s it so big?” Jimin said, trying to climb through the water to get a better look.

           “Stop,” Yoongi said, holding a hand to the boy’s head to stop him from doing so. Jungkook was staring down past his own lap, poking himself experimentally.  “My penis,” he said, emphasizing the word, “is bigger than yours because I’m an adult.  Yours will grow with your body.”

           “Really?” Jimin said, sitting back down.

           “Yes, and you should call things what they are.  It’s not a pee-pee.”

           “Okay,” Jimin hummed.

           “Now, can you get clean while I show you my tattoos?”  The boys assured him they could, and while it was mostly him doing the cleaning of all three of them, and they interrupted him more than they let him just tell them what each meant, they at least got done before the water got too cold.  Satisfied with how clean they both were, Yoongi got out first and found a towel for each of them.  Jungkook once again seemed incapable of taking care of himself, so Yoongi kept him wrapped up until he was dry himself before he gave the boy a final rub down. After brushing their teeth and using the bathroom and making sure everyone was dressed, they both seemed more than compliant enough to go to bed easily, but the moment he got them both under the covers, his back against the wall like he was used to, Jungkook started to cry, and Jimin started to kick him to try to get him to stop, which only made it worse.  Yoongi actually let them for a moment as he took a deep breath.  He felt like crying, too, but he knew he couldn’t.  Instead, with a sigh, he pulled Jungkook away from his brother and laid on his back so the boy could lay on his chest, rubbing his hand up and down his back.

           “He’s being a baby,” Jimin fussed, kicking Yoongi’s leg now.

           “Stop kicking,” Yoongi hissed.  “And leave Jungkook alone.  He’s sad. Let him be sad if he wants to be sad. Go to sleep.”

           “Need a story,” Jimin said, thankfully stopping his kicking.

           “Okay,” Yoongi said, shushing Jungkook and running his fingers through his hair as he tried to think.  “Okay, there were once two boys who were brothers.”  Jungkook sniffed, the topic obviously interesting to him.  “And one time they went out into the woods behind their house.  Their mother had told them to be careful and not get lost.  There was a path they should have stayed on.  But one of the boys wanted to go off of the path.”

           “Oh,” Jimin said, about to put in his two cents about why that was a bad idea, but Yoongi patted his leg and shushed him.

           “He wasn’t sure why he wanted to go off the path.  He had only heard of bad things happening to people who did.  It would be smarter and safer to stay on the path. The boy knew this.  Both boys did.  But the younger brother wanted to anyway, so one day he did.  His brother stayed on the path, and he told his brother, begged his brother, not to leave, but do you know what the younger brother did?”

           “What?” Jimin said.  Jungkook hiccupped.

           “He went anyway.  And his brother thought he would never see him again, but he still managed to come home that night.  The next time they went into the woods, the boy strayed off the path again.  He told his brother it wasn’t that bad, and since he found his way back once, he could find it again.  This went on for years.  The older brother grew more and more worried, and the younger brother grew less and less concerned.  Each time he left the path, he was gone for longer and longer, and it was harder and harder for him to find his way home.  One time, he didn’t come back for so long, his older brother had to go off the path to look for him.  When he found his baby brother, he was so glad, so happy, that he cried and cried. He made his brother promise to never leave the path again, and his brother did.  But he didn’t keep that promise for long.  And eventually, he chose to never come home.  He decided leaving the path was better than staying with his brother.  It was a terrible decision.  It cost him his life.  After being away from his brother for too long, he died.”

           “Oh,” Jimin mumbled, curling up around Yoongi’s arm.  Jungkook’s breath had evened out, and he had mostly gone quiet and still.

           “Yes, oh.”

           “I don’t like this story,” Jimin said, and Yoongi reached down to pat his leg again.

           “I don’t either, Jimin.  Hopefully tomorrow I can come up with a better one.”

           “Okay, Yoo-yoo,” Jimin whispered.  “G’night.”

           “Night Jimin.  Night Jungkook,” Yoongi whispered back.  He waited until the pair was asleep, his mind running through everything he was going to have to do and coming up with five negative explanations for why he wasn’t going to be able to do any of them, before he squeezed his eyes shut and kept them pressed together until they hurt, until his tears finally slipped out. Just a few.  That was all he needed.  One for his brother, and one for himself.  One for Jungkook, and one for Jimin.

A/N:

That’s right, of course Jungkook has a bunny.

That’s right, of course Jimin has a blanket.  And yes, it’s yellow.

Yoongi’s first revealed tattoo is flowers on his left forearm.  He has “Nevermind” on his ribs that Jimin points out.  Yes, I did that.  The other ones will be revealed soon!

Here we begin Jimin and Jungkook living with Yoongi and having Issues.  They’re little kids trying to deal with things they can’t even comprehend.  So don’t expect them to just be cute and OK.

TAE NEXT CHAPTER YAY.
trail.content_abstract:
Summary:  Yoongi loves photography. Taehyung loves photography. Yoongi likes eating good food and dogs and holding hands. Taehyung likes holding hands and dogs and eating good food.  Yoongi does not, dear God, like kids.  Taehyung, thank God, loves kids. But when his brother dies, it’s Yoongi who suddenly has to look after four-year-old Jimin and three-year-old Jungkook.

Aunque sabemos que existen muchísimas, aquí os dejamos 10 covers geniales, ¡por más que las escuchamos nunca dejan de gustarnos!
